Hilbert spaces and their operators provide a mathematical language for quantum theory. This language is powerful and expressive, but it is not the only one. In this paper we provide a purely categorical characterization of Hilbert spaces and their operators. This characterization is based on a class of categories that includes the category of sets and functions, but also many other categories of interest in mathematics and theoretical computer science. Our characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To gain insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the transcriptome and genome of two distantly related myxozoan species to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique resource for understanding the molecular basis of the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy to ensure their replication and propagation. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We quantify the magnitude of this instability and its consequences for global food security. We find that the probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Herbivory is a major driver of ecosystem structure and function, but the extent to which different herbivore species partition food resources is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of herbivores in ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and they are pessimistic about accessing the CARES Act. We also assess the effects of loans relative to grants.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous and growing environmental problem. However, the global load of floating plastic debris in the open ocean is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris in the open ocean is far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. We provide a global map of the distribution of floating plastic debris in the open ocean. This map can be used to assess the magnitude of the problem and to prioritize the implementation of mitigation strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains are the oldest presolar grains known. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of fitness. Reproductive output is limited by maternal energy availability, which is itself limited by maternal metabolic power. All forms of provisioning and allocare correlate with increased reproductive output. All forms of provisioning and allocare correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce α-syn pathology in a mouse model of MSA. Moreover, VX-765 was able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation by reducing its load in the striatum of PLP-SYN mice. Finally, VX-765 showed neuroprotective effects by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of PLP-SYN mice. These results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides proof of concept for a potential therapeutic approach in MSA. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. Cell activities were cross-correlated and compared to a stochastic model to determine network connections. Highly correlated Ca2+ activities occurred in scattered cell clusters, and network communication links between them exhibited unexpectedly short path lengths. The number of connections between cells (degree distribution) followed a power-law relationship revealing a scale-free network topology. The path length and degree distribution revealed an endothelial network with a “small-world” configuration. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data API that provides open access to a rich set of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through a common format, allowing researchers to easily combine and analyze them. The data are also available in a backfilled form, allowing researchers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The data and software are available at no cost and are open source.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a molecular explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. Copyright © 2015. Published

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The gut microbiome is influenced by the host and the microbes within it. The host can influence the microbiome through diet, and the microbiome can influence the host through the production of natural products. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identified 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for diverse types of natural products, including nonribosomal peptide synthetases and polyketide synthases. We also identified seven putative bacteriocins, a class of antimicrobial peptides typically produced by bacteria. These results support the finding that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce bioactive compounds. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in social hierarchy formation remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism

The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great significance for the development of multifunctional devices. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is highly dynamic during development and in response to environmental cues. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is down-regulated during development. IGF2BP1 silencing in adult erythroid tissues causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. The findings may have implications for the development of hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers and hemoglobin-based drugs. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Cancer cells are highly resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, activates sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We show that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that this sensitizing effect is mediated by suppression of SREBP1-dependent lipogenesis. Furthermore, we show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of cancer cells in vivo. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis may be a promising strategy for overcoming ferroptosis resistance in cancer. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure, but the mechanism is unknown. We show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling pathways that promote vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in younger patients with hypertension. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of this policy on biodiversity. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition. However, against our expectations, declines of older-forest–associated bird populations accelerated. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need to continue to monitor the effects of the NWFP and to evaluate its effectiveness. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art results in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and automatically adapts to different problems. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous in Western societies. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book before bedtime had reduced melatonin levels and were phase-delayed in their circadian clock. These effects were associated with reduced sleepiness and increased sleep efficiency. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also provides a rationale for the development of electronic devices that are designed to promote sleep. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1.2- to 1.5-year period of abrupt climate change that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD boundary. We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YD sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. In contrast, bulk sediments from YD sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania exhibit 187Os/188Os ratios <<1.0 and at face value suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os. CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deficiency induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. CTLA-4 deficiency also induced preferential expansion of Treg cells, but this was not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity. In addition, CTLA-4 deficiency had opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. These findings provide a rationale for the use of CTLA-4 as a therapeutic target in autoimmune diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that beetles use to digest plant cell walls, and found that these may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in parallel with angiosperms, and that the ability to digest plant cell walls may have enabled the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. These results provide insights into the origin of beetle diversity and the factors that have driven its subsequent evolution. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has necessitated the development of new vaccines and therapeutics. However, the emergence of variants with reduced or lost neutralization activity has hindered the development of such products. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s neutralization activity against Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Copyright © 2022. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population and become more common over time. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance CCE. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, but that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of culture in general and for the design of interventions to promote cultural change.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. APOE4 accelerates the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the stable hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the main phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective for understanding the formation of the inner core. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Marijuana abuse is a major public health concern. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana abuse on brain reactivity to dopamine (DA) stimulation are unknown. We investigated the effects of chronic marijuana abuse on brain DA reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular DA. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly blunted responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana abuse may impair brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. These findings also highlight the urgency to investigate effects of chronic marijuana abuse in the human brain. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and its neural basis is a major focus of neuroscience. We show that the most accurate machine-learning models of language processing in the human brain are also the simplest. These models are based on recurrent neural networks, which have been shown to be effective in other domains, but have not previously been applied to language. Our results suggest that the language system in the human brain is simple and efficient, and that predictive processing plays a central role. This approach provides a promising avenue for future research on the neural basis of higher-level cognition. (Read less)

Deep learning (DL) has achieved unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear why DL works so well. One of the most important reasons is that DL is a black box, and we do not know how to analyze its properties. In this paper, we show that the black box of DL can be opened by understanding the stability of its internal computation. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of stability and instability of NNs. We also introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the 1975 classic experiment by Daniel Kahneman, Jack Knetsch, and Levy (KKL). The study is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s design flaws were not noticed at the time and are discussed here. The flaws are a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae that affects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the nose. A second, less-studied disease, diffuse lepromatous leprosy, is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, a reactional pathogen, and compared it with that of M. leprae, the nerve-pathogenic species. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost the ability to do so. We also found that the two species are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings have implications for leprosy treatment and for the study of ancient human pathogens. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems is a long-standing open problem. We provide a complete solution to this problem for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is integrable and thus allows for a complete analytical treatment. Our result is based on a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, which is supported by integrability. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a set of coupled nonlinear differential equations, which can be solved exactly. We check our result for the ground state and the first excited state.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. A vaccine is urgently needed to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is highly attenuated and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate generates high levels of spike-specific antibodies and neutralizing antibodies in hamsters. In addition, the vaccine candidate protects hamsters from weight loss upon lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. These results support the potential of COVI-VAC for use in mass vaccination programs. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for future studies on the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other infectious diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. Interestingly, relative brain size is associated with relative neuronal cell density in reptiles, birds, and primates but not in other mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results suggest that the evolution of brain neuronal density is a key factor in the rise of complex cognition. Copyright ©

Mitochondrial HSP90 family member TRAP1 is a potential therapeutic target in cancer. However, the utility of TRAP1 inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function is limited by the fact that they cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. We describe a large-scale, resource-scarce setting mNGS pathogen surveillance study of undifferentiated febrile illness. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short Okazaki fragments. The polymerase responsible for this process, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ), is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by RNA enzymes. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of RNA-based life. (Read more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. Tocilizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against interleukin 6, which has been proved to be effective in treating rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases. In this study, we found that tocilizumab could reduce mortality in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is a promising therapeutic strategy.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) encodes a family of isocyanide-containing metabolites that bind copper. Here we demonstrate that copper-binding xanthocillin metabolites are secreted by Aspergillus fumigatus, where they impact copper content and have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. Late-spring frosts (LSFs) are a major source of economic losses in agriculture and forestry, but the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We use a dataset of LSFs and the resistance strategies of woody plants to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our results reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our findings also provide a framework for studying the evolutionary impact of frost events on plants. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model. Instead, they required the development of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells, which were capable of inducing colitis. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Furthermore, they indicate that the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors may be a therapeutic target in inflammatory bowel disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins and by superoxide dismutase and hexanucleotide expansion in the C9orf72 gene. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate motor neuron toxicity in ALS. It will also enable the study of the role of astrocytes in ALS. This will lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates pathogen colonization. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod microbiome and may have implications for vector-borne disease transmission. Copyright © 2015. The origin of the avian tail and its function are among the most fundamental questions in avian evolution. The discovery of a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. Our results suggest that stratospheric water vapor should be included in climate models. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, ranging from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to assess its physiological state, communicate with conspecifics, and avoid predation. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be modulated by the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main chromophore of phytochromes and bacteriophytochromes. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings can be used to understand the evolution of color in vertebrates and to develop new tools for biomedical applications. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Hypoxia is a hallmark of many cancers, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key regulators of the hypoxic phenotype. We report that HIF-dependent expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5) increases the proportion of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) in MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and ALKBH5-dependent NANOG mRNA demethylation increases NANOG mRNA levels, which in turn increases the proportion of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes BCSC enrichment. Our findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for breast cancer. Copyright © 2015. The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. We report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key control on the timing of the carbon cycle reorganization and the timing of ecosystem recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath based on a new set of U-Pb dates from the Meishan section in China. The age model reveals that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization occurred ∼100 ka before the extinction. The carbon cycle reorganization and ecosystem recovery persisted for ∼500 ka. The age model will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Copyright © 2015. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is characterized by excessive inflammation and immune responses, which lead to intestinal barrier dysfunction and tissue damage. IBD is a heterogeneous disease, and the underlying mechanisms are complex. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for IBD. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence of the D614G mutation and the wild-type protein. We find that the mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations. These conformational changes may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase infectivity.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even when the action sets are finite. The proof also yields a characterization of the set of games that admit an ε-equilibrium for every ε>0.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and physics. In this work, we propose a pressure-dependent chemical potential for atoms, which is based on the electronegativity and chemical hardness of atoms. We show that the proposed chemical potential is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the proposed chemical potential can be used to predict the behavior of elements under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and its effects on climate. We find that climate change has already warmed the global fire regime, but that human demography has suppressed global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems. However, climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions and fire suppression in shaping fire regimes and the potential for climate change to exacerbate or attenuate these effects. This could have implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study also highlights the need to understand feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon in fire-dependent ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain stable, beneficial relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is released by host hemocytes in the late afternoon, when the squid is preparing to produce light. Chitin catabolism by the symbionts is required for a periodic acidification of the host crypts, which increases the level of oxygen available to the symbionts and enhances their capacity to produce light at night. This glycan-nutrient provision may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify latent patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent topics. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This work is a step toward understanding and modeling the latent patterns in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not caused by a single introduction of Y. pestis, but rather by multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a long period of adaptation. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Mass mortality events of asteroids are rare and have been linked to epizootics of viruses. Here, we report the isolation of a densovirus from diseased asteroids and provide evidence that it is the causative agent of the mass mortality event. The virus is likely to be a major threat to the ecosystem and to fisheries.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of therapeutic targets is a major challenge. We show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells in xenograft models. We further show that this antibody is able to target primary human AML cells. These results provide evidence that IL1RAP can be targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling. This antibody may be useful for the treatment of AML. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for future studies on the settlement history of other islands. Copyright © 2015. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has necessitated the development of new vaccines and therapeutics. However, the emergence of variants with reduced or lost neutralization activity has hampered the development of such products. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s neutralization activity against Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Copyright © 2022. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information for agricultural decision-making. However, they are often overlooked in favor of more sophisticated models and remote sensing. We show that crop expert surveys can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting crop condition index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results suggest that crop expert surveys can be a valuable source of information for agricultural decision-making. This approach can be extended to other agricultural variables, such as soil moisture, to provide early warnings of drought. Our findings have implications for agricultural decision-making, climate change adaptation, and disaster relief.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the study of the origin and evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes reach several new rate equilibria during the functional reduction process. The evolutionary rates of plastid genes are linked to macrostructural and microstructural changes, the extent of functional reduction, and the establishment of the obligate parasitic lifestyle. These findings provide a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the most severe in the past century. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of anthropogenic climate change. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized condensed matter physics. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated EAE. ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes also ameliorated EAE, but only in the later stage. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to anthropogenic warming. We also find that the probability of drought has increased when precipitation deficits are combined with warm conditions. This finding suggests that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This conclusion is supported by a large ensemble of climate model simulations. The results have important implications for water resources management and climate change adaptation. They also highlight the importance of anthropogenic warming in California’s current drought. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, but that individual-level variation in responsiveness is considerable. This work also highlights the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry channel, the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) or store-operated Ca2+ current (SOCC), is activated by the binding of inositol trisphosphate (IP3) or diacylglycerol (DAG) to the IP3 receptor (IP3R) and the stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1)/Orai1 complex, respectively. Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the management of ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It contains two subregions, the superficial layer (MECs) and the deep layer (parasubiculum). The organization of neurons in MECs is not well understood. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to examine the topographic arrangement of neurons in MECs and adjacent parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are critical for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings provide a foundation for future studies of the organization of navigation circuits in MEC. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from host to parasite and activate flowering in the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of how a plant hormone can function as an important interplant flowering signal. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal pathway is a critical component of the brain’s dopamine system. We show that the striatonigral fibers that innervate the striatum form unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies. These dendrites are part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected? We conducted a large-scale study in which people talked with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed with which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal was used by third-party listeners to predict how connected people felt. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for heart rate regulation. SAN cells are characterized by the presence of specialized Ca2+ release units, which are regulated by the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway. We report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SAN cells and regulates Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of SAN cells. We also show that STIM1 regulates the activity of the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway and the L-type Ca2+ current in SAN cells. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in Ca2+ signaling in SAN cells. Our findings suggest that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plants, but its role in plant defense against herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice. We also show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder by priming jasmonate (JA) signaling, which is mediated by the JA biosynthetic enzyme allene oxide synthase and the JA perception enzyme CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1. These results suggest that Si priming of JA signaling is a key mechanism underlying Si-enhanced resistance against herbivory. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we show that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has profound effects on the lipidome. These results provide a basis for further studies on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical bottleneck in the field of synthetic biology. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants and that the delivery efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a foundation for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Nutrient pollution is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small watersheds that drain into large water bodies. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small watersheds largely unmonitored. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all watersheds of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that small watersheds can be important sources of coastal nutrient pollution. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a critical link between land use and coastal eutrophication. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combination of initial conditions that led to the observed universe is biased toward a fine-tuned extremization of the cosmological constant. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning problem may be more general, and may apply to a wide range of systems that are far from equilibrium.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic properties of cortical microcircuits to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other pathogenic antibodies on brain function. This work may also have implications for other autoimmune diseases in which antibodies disrupt synaptic function. Copyright © 2018. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Cretaceous–Paleogene mass extinction and the subsequent recovery of biodiversity are well documented, but the history of abrupt warming events is less well understood. Here, we present a multiproxy study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a global cooling event. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that the warming was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. This study provides insights into the history of abrupt warming events and their potential impacts on the Earth system. It also provides a case study for the use of multiproxy and modeling approaches to investigate abrupt warming events. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Certification of palm oil production is a key policy tool for reducing deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire remains unclear. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. We find that certification reduced deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certified areas held less than 1% of forests remaining within Indonesian oil palm plantations in 2015. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Sex determination is a fundamental evolutionary process that shapes the sex ratio, sex-specific traits, and sex-specific behaviors of a species. In vertebrates, sex determination is often regulated by a single locus, which can result in two sexes, three sexes, or more. In contrast, species with polygenic sex determination have multiple alleles segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination alleles is critical for predicting the effects of anthropogenic change on species diversity. Copyright © 2015.
